title: How many episodes of World On Fire will there be and who’s in the cast?
text:
We’re about halfway through the series… (Picture: Dusan Martincek/BBC/Mammoth Screen)

The third episode of World War II drama World On Fire will be airing tonight, 13 October.

The series follows civilians who become caught up in the war and one way or another must struggle to survive.

As we wait for the next episode, here’s a quick look at how many episodes there will be, who’s in the cast, and where you might have seen their faces before.

How many episodes of World On Fire are there?

There will be a total of seven episodes of World On Fire.

There’s been no word yet as to whether or not there will be a second season.

Who’s in the cast of World On Fire?

Jonah Hauer-King as Harry Chase

Julia Brown as Lois Bennett

Zofia Wichlacz as Kasia Tomaszeski

Yrsa Daley-Ward as Connie

Parker Sawyers as Albert

Brian J. Smith as Webster

João Rei Villar as Chef

Sean Bean as Douglas Bennett

Helen Hunt as Nancy Campbell

Where have you seen the cast before?

Jonah Hauer-King is no stranger to period dramas, having appeared in the likes of Little Women (2017), Ashes in the Snow (2018) and Howards End (2017), as well as Postcards from London (2018)

You might recognise Julia Brown from M.I. High (2014), Shetland (2018) and Grasslands (2018), while Polish-born Zofia has acted in Warsaw ’44 (2014), Spoor (2017) and Amok (2017).

Yrsa Daley-Ward was in episodes of Drop Dead Gorgeous (2007) and Shameless (2009), as well as Der Koch (2014) and White Colour Black (2016).

Sean Bean as Douglas Bennett (Picture: Ben Blackall/BBC/Mammoth Screen)

Hollywood heavyweights Sean Bean and Helen Hunt also feature in World On Fire as Douglas Bennett and Nancy Campbell respectively.

Hunt has acted in such films as As Good as It Gets (1997), Twister (1996), and Cast Away (2000).

You’ll likely know Bean from the likes of Game of Thrones (2011), Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (2001), The Martian (2015), and National Treasure (2004).

Bean, who is famous for playing characters who end up dying, made sure that his character survives this show, saying at a press event: ‘It was a telephone conversation and I said, “I don’t die in this one, do I?” and [creator Peter Bowker] said, “No, no you’ll be fine. You’re alright.”’

World On Fire airs Sunday nights on BBC One.
